verses.text: But they replied, ‘We do not drink wine, because our forefather Jehonadab son of Rekab gave us this command: “Neither you nor your descendants must ever drink wine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also you must never build houses, sow seed or plant vineyards; you must never have any of these things, but must always live in tents. Then you will live a long time in the land where you are nomads.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We have obeyed everything our forefather Jehonadab son of Rekab commanded us. Neither we nor our wives nor our sons and daughters have ever drunk wine
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: or built houses to live in or had vineyards, fields or crops.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We have lived in tents and have fully obeyed everything our forefather Jehonadab commanded us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon invaded this land, we said, “Come, we must go to Jerusalem to escape the Babylonian and Aramean armies.” So we have remained in Jerusalem.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the word of the Lord came to Jeremiah, saying:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘This is what the Lord Almighty, the God of Israel, says: go and tell the people of Judah and those living in Jerusalem, “Will you not learn a lesson and obey my words?” declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Jehonadab son of Rekab ordered his descendants not to drink wine and this command has been kept. To this day they do not drink wine, because they obey their forefather’s command. But I have spoken to you again and again, yet you have not obeyed me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Again and again I sent all my servants the prophets to you. They said, ‘Each of you must turn from your wicked ways and reform your actions; do not follow other gods to serve them. Then you shall live in the land I have given to you and your ancestors.’ But you have not paid attention or listened to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The descendants of Jehonadab son of Rekab have carried out the command their forefather gave them, but these people have not obeyed me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Therefore this is what the Lord God Almighty, the God of Israel, says: “Listen! I am going to bring on Judah and on everyone living in Jerusalem every disaster I pronounced against them. I spoke to them, but they did not listen; I called to them, but they did not answer.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeremiah said to the family of the Rekabites, ‘This is what the Lord Almighty, the God of Israel, says: “You have obeyed the command of your forefather Jehonadab and have followed all his instructions and have done everything he ordered.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore this is what the Lord Almighty, the God of Israel, says: “Jehonadab son of Rekab shall never fail to have a descendant to serve me.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the fourth year of Jehoiakim son of Josiah king of Judah, this word came to Jeremiah from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Take a scroll and write on it all the words I have spoken to you concerning Israel, Judah and all the other nations from the time I began speaking to you in the reign of Josiah till now.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Perhaps when the people of Judah hear about every disaster I plan to inflict on them, they will each turn from their wicked ways; then I will forgive their wickedness and their sin.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jeremiah called Baruch son of Neriah, and while Jeremiah dictated all the words the Lord had spoken to him, Baruch wrote them on the scroll.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeremiah told Baruch, ‘I am restricted; I am not allowed to go to the Lord’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So you go to the house of the Lord on a day of fasting and read to the people from the scroll the words of the Lord that you wrote as I dictated. Read them to all the people of Judah who come in from their towns.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Perhaps they will bring their petition before the Lord and will each turn from their wicked ways, for the anger and wrath pronounced against this people by the Lord are great.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Baruch son of Neriah did everything Jeremiah the prophet told him to do; at the Lord’s temple he read the words of the Lord from the scroll.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the ninth month of the fifth year of Jehoiakim son of Josiah king of Judah, a time of fasting before the Lord was proclaimed for all the people in Jerusalem and those who had come from the towns of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From the room of Gemariah son of Shaphan the secretary, which was in the upper courtyard at the entrance of the New Gate of the temple, Baruch read to all the people at the Lord’s temple the words of Jeremiah from the scroll.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Micaiah son of Gemariah, the son of Shaphan, heard all the words of the Lord from the scroll,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he went down to the secretary’s room in the royal palace, where all the officials were sitting: Elishama the secretary, Delaiah son of Shemaiah, Elnathan son of Akbor, Gemariah son of Shaphan, Zedekiah son of Hananiah, and all the other officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Micaiah told them everything he had heard Baruch read to the people from the scroll,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: all the officials sent Jehudi son of Nethaniah, the son of Shelemiah, the son of Cushi, to say to Baruch, ‘Bring the scroll from which you have read to the people and come.’ So Baruch son of Neriah went to them with the scroll in his hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They said to him, ‘Sit down, please, and read it to us.’
So Baruch read it to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they heard all these words, they looked at each other in fear and said to Baruch, ‘We must report all these words to the king.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they asked Baruch, ‘Tell us, how did you come to write all this? Did Jeremiah dictate it?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Yes,’ Baruch replied, ‘he dictated all these words to me, and I wrote them in ink on the scroll.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the officials said to Baruch, ‘You and Jeremiah, go and hide. Don’t let anyone know where you are.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After they put the scroll in the room of Elishama the secretary, they went to the king in the courtyard and reported everything to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king sent Jehudi to get the scroll, and Jehudi brought it from the room of Elishama the secretary and read it to the king and all the officials standing beside him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It was the ninth month and the king was sitting in the winter apartment, with a fire burning in the brazier in front of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever Jehudi had read three or four columns of the scroll, the king cut them off with a scribe’s knife and threw them into the brazier, until the entire scroll was burned in the fire.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king and all his attendants who heard all these words showed no fear, nor did they tear their clothes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even though Elnathan, Delaiah and Gemariah urged the king not to burn the scroll, he would not listen to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Instead, the king commanded Jerahmeel, a son of the king, Seraiah son of Azriel and Shelemiah son of Abdeel to arrest Baruch the scribe and Jeremiah the prophet. But the Lord had hidden them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the king burned the scroll containing the words that Baruch had written at Jeremiah’s dictation, the word of the Lord came to Jeremiah:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Take another scroll and write on it all the words that were on the first scroll, which Jehoiakim king of Judah burned up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also tell Jehoiakim king of Judah, “This is what the Lord says: you burned that scroll and said, ‘Why did you write on it that the king of Babylon would certainly come and destroy this land and wipe from it both man and beast?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore this is what the Lord says about Jehoiakim king of Judah: he will have no one to sit on the throne of David; his body will be thrown out and exposed to the heat by day and the frost by night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will punish him and his children and his attendants for their wickedness; I will bring on them and those living in Jerusalem and the people of Judah every disaster I pronounced against them, because they have not listened.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jeremiah took another scroll and gave it to the scribe Baruch son of Neriah, and as Jeremiah dictated, Baruch wrote on it all the words of the scroll that Jehoiakim king of Judah had burned in the fire. And many similar words were added to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zedekiah son of Josiah was made king of Judah by Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon; he reigned in place of Jehoiachin son of Jehoiakim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Neither he nor his attendants nor the people of the land paid any attention to the words the Lord had spoken through Jeremiah the prophet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Zedekiah, however, sent Jehukal son of Shelemiah with the priest Zephaniah son of Maaseiah to Jeremiah the prophet with this message: ‘Please pray to the Lord our God for us.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Jeremiah was free to come and go among the people, for he had not yet been put in prison.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh’s army had marched out of Egypt, and when the Babylonians who were besieging Jerusalem heard the report about them, they withdrew from Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the word of the Lord came to Jeremiah the prophet:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: tell the king of Judah, who sent you to enquire of me, “Pharaoh’s army, which has marched out to support you, will go back to its own land, to Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Babylonians will return and attack this city; they will capture it and burn it down.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘This is what the Lord says: do not deceive yourselves, thinking, “The Babylonians will surely leave us.” They will not!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even if you were to defeat the entire Babylonian army that is attacking you and only wounded men were left in their tents, they would come out and burn this city down.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the Babylonian army had withdrawn from Jerusalem because of Pharaoh’s army,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah started to leave the city to go to the territory of Benjamin to get his share of the property among the people there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when he reached the Benjamin Gate, the captain of the guard, whose name was Irijah son of Shelemiah, the son of Hananiah, arrested him and said, ‘You are deserting to the Babylonians!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘That’s not true!’ Jeremiah said. ‘I am not deserting to the Babylonians.’ But Irijah would not listen to him; instead, he arrested Jeremiah and brought him to the officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They were angry with Jeremiah and had him beaten and imprisoned in the house of Jonathan the secretary, which they had made into a prison.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah was put into a vaulted cell in a dungeon, where he remained a long time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then King Zedekiah sent for him and had him brought to the palace, where he asked him privately, ‘Is there any word from the Lord?’
‘Yes,’ Jeremiah replied, ‘you will be delivered into the hands of the king of Babylon.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeremiah said to King Zedekiah, ‘What crime have I committed against you or your attendants or this people, that you have put me in prison?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Where are your prophets who prophesied to you, “The king of Babylon will not attack you or this land”?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now, my lord the king, please listen. Let me bring my petition before you: do not send me back to the house of Jonathan the secretary, or I shall die there.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Zedekiah then gave orders for Jeremiah to be placed in the courtyard of the guard and given a loaf of bread from the street of the bakers each day until all the bread in the city was gone. So Jeremiah remained in the courtyard of the guard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shephatiah son of Mattan, Gedaliah son of Pashhur, Jehukal son of Shelemiah, and Pashhur son of Malkijah heard what Jeremiah was telling all the people when he said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘This is what the Lord says: “Whoever stays in this city will die by the sword, famine or plague, but whoever goes over to the Babylonians will live. They will escape with their lives; they will live.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And this is what the Lord says: “This city will certainly be given into the hands of the army of the king of Babylon, who will capture it.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the officials said to the king, ‘This man should be put to death. He is discouraging the soldiers who are left in this city, as well as all the people, by the things he is saying to them. This man is not seeking the good of these people but their ruin.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘He is in your hands,’ King Zedekiah answered. ‘The king can do nothing to oppose you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they took Jeremiah and put him into the cistern of Malkijah, the king’s son, which was in the courtyard of the guard. They lowered Jeremiah by ropes into the cistern; it had no water in it, only mud, and Jeremiah sank down into the mud.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Ebed-Melek, a Cushite, an official in the royal palace, heard that they had put Jeremiah into the cistern. While the king was sitting in the Benjamin Gate,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ebed-Melek went out of the palace and said to him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘My lord the king, these men have acted wickedly in all they have done to Jeremiah the prophet. They have thrown him into a cistern, where he will starve to death when there is no longer any bread in the city.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king commanded Ebed-Melek the Cushite, ‘Take thirty men from here with you and lift Jeremiah the prophet out of the cistern before he dies.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Ebed-Melek took the men with him and went to a room under the treasury in the palace. He took some old rags and worn-out clothes from there and let them down with ropes to Jeremiah in the cistern.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ebed-Melek the Cushite said to Jeremiah, ‘Put these old rags and worn-out clothes under your arms to pad the ropes.’ Jeremiah did so,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and they pulled him up with the ropes and lifted him out of the cistern. And Jeremiah remained in the courtyard of the guard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King Zedekiah sent for Jeremiah the prophet and had him brought to the third entrance to the temple of the Lord. ‘I am going to ask you something,’ the king said to Jeremiah. ‘Do not hide anything from me.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah said to Zedekiah, ‘If I give you an answer, will you not kill me? Even if I did give you counsel, you would not listen to me.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But King Zedekiah swore this oath secretly to Jeremiah: ‘As surely as the Lord lives, who has given us breath, I will neither kill you nor hand you over to those who want to kill you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeremiah said to Zedekiah, ‘This is what the Lord God Almighty, the God of Israel, says: “If you surrender to the officers of the king of Babylon, your life will be spared and this city will not be burned down; you and your family will live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you will not surrender to the officers of the king of Babylon, this city will be given into the hands of the Babylonians and they will burn it down; you yourself will not escape from them.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Zedekiah said to Jeremiah, ‘I am afraid of the Jews who have gone over to the Babylonians, for the Babylonians may hand me over to them and they will ill-treat me.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘They will not hand you over,’ Jeremiah replied. ‘Obey the Lord by doing what I tell you. Then it will go well with you, and your life will be spared.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you refuse to surrender, this is what the Lord has revealed to me:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
all the women left in the palace of the king of Judah will be brought out to the officials of the king of Babylon. Those women will say to you:
‘“They misled you and overcame you –
    those trusted friends of yours.
Your feet are sunk in the mud;
    your friends have deserted you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘All your wives and children will be brought out to the Babylonians. You yourself will not escape from their hands but will be captured by the king of Babylon; and this city will be burned down.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Zedekiah said to Jeremiah, ‘Do not let anyone know about this conversation, or you may die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the officials hear that I talked with you, and they come to you and say, “Tell us what you said to the king and what the king said to you; do not hide it from us or we will kill you,”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then tell them, “I was pleading with the king not to send me back to Jonathan’s house to die there.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the officials did come to Jeremiah and question him, and he told them everything the king had ordered him to say. So they said no more to him, for no one had heard his conversation with the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And Jeremiah remained in the courtyard of the guard until the day Jerusalem was captured.
This is how Jerusalem was taken:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: in the ninth year of Zedekiah king of Judah, in the tenth month, Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon marched against Jerusalem with his whole army and laid siege to it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And on the ninth day of the fourth month of Zedekiah’s eleventh year, the city wall was broken through.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the officials of the king of Babylon came and took seats in the Middle Gate: Nergal-Sharezer of Samgar, Nebo-Sarsekim a chief officer, Nergal-Sharezer a high official and all the other officials of the king of Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Zedekiah king of Judah and all the soldiers saw them, they fled; they left the city at night by way of the king’s garden, through the gate between the two walls, and headed towards the Arabah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Babylonian army pursued them and overtook Zedekiah in the plains of Jericho. They captured him and took him to Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon at Riblah in the land of Hamath, where he pronounced sentence on him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There at Riblah the king of Babylon slaughtered the sons of Zedekiah before his eyes and also killed all the nobles of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he put out Zedekiah’s eyes and bound him with bronze shackles to take him to Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Babylonians set fire to the royal palace and the houses of the people and broke down the walls of Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nebuzaradan commander of the imperial guard carried into exile to Babylon the people who remained in the city, along with those who had gone over to him, and the rest of the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Nebuzaradan the commander of the guard left behind in the land of Judah some of the poor people, who owned nothing; and at that time he gave them vineyards and fields.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon had given these orders about Jeremiah through Nebuzaradan commander of the imperial guard:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Take him and look after him; don’t harm him but do for him whatever he asks.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Nebuzaradan the commander of the guard, Nebushazban a chief officer, Nergal-Sharezer a high official and all the other officers of the king of Babylon
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: sent and had Jeremiah taken out of the courtyard of the guard. They handed him over to Gedaliah son of Ahikam, the son of Shaphan, to take him back to his home. So he remained among his own people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Jeremiah had been confined in the courtyard of the guard, the word of the Lord came to him:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Go and tell Ebed-Melek the Cushite, “This is what the Lord Almighty, the God of Israel, says: I am about to fulfil my words against this city – words concerning disaster, not prosperity. At that time they will be fulfilled before your eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I will rescue you on that day, declares the Lord; you will not be given into the hands of those you fear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will save you; you will not fall by the sword but will escape with your life, because you trust in me, declares the Lord.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The word came to Jeremiah from the Lord after Nebuzaradan commander of the imperial guard had released him at Ramah. He had found Jeremiah bound in chains among all the captives from Jerusalem and Judah who were being carried into exile to Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the commander of the guard found Jeremiah, he said to him, ‘The Lord your God decreed this disaster for this place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And now the Lord has brought it about; he has done just as he said he would. All this happened because you people sinned against the Lord and did not obey him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But today I am freeing you from the chains on your wrists. Come with me to Babylon, if you like, and I will look after you; but if you do not want to, then don’t come. Look, the whole country lies before you; go wherever you please.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
However, before Jeremiah turned to go, Nebuzaradan added, ‘Go back to Gedaliah son of Ahikam, the son of Shaphan, whom the king of Babylon has appointed over the towns of Judah, and live with him among the people, or go anywhere else you please.’
Then the commander gave him provisions and a present and let him go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jeremiah went to Gedaliah son of Ahikam at Mizpah and stayed with him among the people who were left behind in the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all the army officers and their men who were still in the open country heard that the king of Babylon had appointed Gedaliah son of Ahikam as governor over the land and had put him in charge of the men, women and children who were the poorest in the land and who had not been carried into exile to Babylon,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: they came to Gedaliah at Mizpah – Ishmael son of Nethaniah, Johanan and Jonathan the sons of Kareah, Seraiah son of Tanhumeth, the sons of Ephai the Netophathite, and Jaazaniah the son of the Maakathite, and their men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gedaliah son of Ahikam, the son of Shaphan, took an oath to reassure them and their men. ‘Do not be afraid to serve the Babylonians,’ he said. ‘Settle down in the land and serve the king of Babylon, and it will go well with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I myself will stay in Mizpah to represent you before the Babylonians who come to us, but you are to harvest the wine, summer fruit and olive oil, and put them in your storage jars, and live in the towns you have taken over.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all the Jews in Moab, Ammon, Edom and all the other countries heard that the king of Babylon had left a remnant in Judah and had appointed Gedaliah son of Ahikam, the son of Shaphan, as governor over them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: they all came back to the land of Judah, to Gedaliah at Mizpah, from all the countries where they had been scattered. And they harvested an abundance of wine and summer fruit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Johanan son of Kareah and all the army officers still in the open country came to Gedaliah at Mizpah
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and said to him, ‘Don’t you know that Baalis king of the Ammonites has sent Ishmael son of Nethaniah to take your life?’ But Gedaliah son of Ahikam did not believe them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Johanan son of Kareah said privately to Gedaliah in Mizpah, ‘Let me go and kill Ishmael son of Nethaniah, and no one will know it. Why should he take your life and cause all the Jews who are gathered around you to be scattered and the remnant of Judah to perish?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Gedaliah son of Ahikam said to Johanan son of Kareah, ‘Don’t do such a thing! What you are saying about Ishmael is not true.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the seventh month Ishmael son of Nethaniah, the son of Elishama, who was of royal blood and had been one of the king’s officers, came with ten men to Gedaliah son of Ahikam at Mizpah. While they were eating together there,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ishmael son of Nethaniah and the ten men who were with him got up and struck down Gedaliah son of Ahikam, the son of Shaphan, with the sword, killing the one whom the king of Babylon had appointed as governor over the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ishmael also killed all the men of Judah who were with Gedaliah at Mizpah, as well as the Babylonian soldiers who were there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The day after Gedaliah’s assassination, before anyone knew about it,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: eighty men who had shaved off their beards, torn their clothes and cut themselves came from Shechem, Shiloh and Samaria, bringing grain offerings and incense with them to the house of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ishmael son of Nethaniah went out from Mizpah to meet them, weeping as he went. When he met them, he said, ‘Come to Gedaliah son of Ahikam.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they went into the city, Ishmael son of Nethaniah and the men who were with him slaughtered them and threw them into a cistern.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But ten of them said to Ishmael, ‘Don’t kill us! We have wheat and barley, olive oil and honey, hidden in a field.’ So he let them alone and did not kill them with the others.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the cistern where he threw all the bodies of the men he had killed along with Gedaliah was the one King Asa had made as part of his defence against Baasha king of Israel. Ishmael son of Nethaniah filled it with the dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ishmael made captives of all the rest of the people who were in Mizpah – the king’s daughters along with all the others who were left there, over whom Nebuzaradan commander of the imperial guard had appointed Gedaliah son of Ahikam. Ishmael son of Nethaniah took them captive and set out to cross over to the Ammonites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Johanan son of Kareah and all the army officers who were with him heard about all the crimes Ishmael son of Nethaniah had committed,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: they took all their men and went to fight Ishmael son of Nethaniah. They caught up with him near the great pool in Gibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all the people Ishmael had with him saw Johanan son of Kareah and the army officers who were with him, they were glad.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people Ishmael had taken captive at Mizpah turned and went over to Johanan son of Kareah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Ishmael son of Nethaniah and eight of his men escaped from Johanan and fled to the Ammonites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Johanan son of Kareah and all the army officers who were with him led away all the people of Mizpah who had survived, whom Johanan had recovered from Ishmael son of Nethaniah after Ishmael had assassinated Gedaliah son of Ahikam – the soldiers, women, children and court officials he had recovered from Gibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And they went on, stopping at Geruth Kimham near Bethlehem on their way to Egypt
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: to escape the Babylonians. They were afraid of them because Ishmael son of Nethaniah had killed Gedaliah son of Ahikam, whom the king of Babylon had appointed as governor over the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the army officers, including Johanan son of Kareah and Jezaniah son of Hoshaiah, and all the people from the least to the greatest approached
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah the prophet and said to him, ‘Please hear our petition and pray to the Lord your God for this entire remnant. For as you now see, though we were once many, now only a few are left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pray that the Lord your God will tell us where we should go and what we should do.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘I have heard you,’ replied Jeremiah the prophet. ‘I will certainly pray to the Lord your God as you have requested; I will tell you everything the Lord says and will keep nothing back from you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they said to Jeremiah, ‘May the Lord be a true and faithful witness against us if we do not act in accordance with everything the Lord your God sends you to tell us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whether it is favourable or unfavourable, we will obey the Lord our God, to whom we are sending you, so that it will go well with us, for we will obey the Lord our God.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ten days later the word of the Lord came to Jeremiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he called together Johanan son of Kareah and all the army officers who were with him and all the people from the least to the greatest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to them, ‘This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, to whom you sent me to present your petition, says:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If you stay in this land, I will build you up and not tear you down; I will plant you and not uproot you, for I have relented concerning the disaster I have inflicted on you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not be afraid of the king of Babylon, whom you now fear. Do not be afraid of him, declares the Lord, for I am with you and will save you and deliver you from his hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will show you compassion so that he will have compassion on you and restore you to your land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘However, if you say, “We will not stay in this land,” and so disobey the Lord your God,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and if you say, “No, we will go and live in Egypt, where we will not see war or hear the trumpet or be hungry for bread,”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then hear the word of the Lord, you remnant of Judah. This is what the Lord Almighty, the God of Israel, says: “If you are determined to go to Egypt and you do go to settle there,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then the sword you fear will overtake you there, and the famine you dread will follow you into Egypt, and there you will die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Indeed, all who are determined to go to Egypt to settle there will die by the sword, famine and plague; not one of them will survive or escape the disaster I will bring on them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord Almighty, the God of Israel, says: “As my anger and wrath have been poured out on those who lived in Jerusalem, so will my wrath be poured out on you when you go to Egypt. You will be a curse and an object of horror, a curse and an object of reproach; you will never see this place again.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Remnant of Judah, the Lord has told you, “Do not go to Egypt.” Be sure of this: I warn you today
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: that you made a fatal mistake when you sent me to the Lord your God and said, “Pray to the Lord our God for us; tell us everything he says and we will do it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have told you today, but you still have not obeyed the Lord your God in all he sent me to tell you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So now, be sure of this: you will die by the sword, famine and plague in the place where you want to go to settle.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jeremiah had finished telling the people all the words of the Lord their God – everything the Lord had sent him to tell them –
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Azariah son of Hoshaiah and Johanan son of Kareah and all the arrogant men said to Jeremiah, ‘You are lying! The Lord our God has not sent you to say, “You must not go to Egypt to settle there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Baruch son of Neriah is inciting you against us to hand us over to the Babylonians, so that they may kill us or carry us into exile to Babylon.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Johanan son of Kareah and all the army officers and all the people disobeyed the Lord’s command to stay in the land of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Instead, Johanan son of Kareah and all the army officers led away all the remnant of Judah who had come back to live in the land of Judah from all the nations where they had been scattered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They also led away all those whom Nebuzaradan commander of the imperial guard had left with Gedaliah son of Ahikam, the son of Shaphan – the men, the women, the children and the king’s daughters. And they took Jeremiah the prophet and Baruch son of Neriah along with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they entered Egypt in disobedience to the Lord and went as far as Tahpanhes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In Tahpanhes the word of the Lord came to Jeremiah:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘While the Jews are watching, take some large stones with you and bury them in clay in the brick pavement at the entrance to Pharaoh’s palace in Tahpanhes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then say to them, “This is what the Lord Almighty, the God of Israel, says: I will send for my servant Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, and I will set his throne over these stones I have buried here; he will spread his royal canopy above them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will come and attack Egypt, bringing death to those destined for death, captivity to those destined for captivity, and the sword to those destined for the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will set fire to the temples of the gods of Egypt; he will burn their temples and take their gods captive. As a shepherd picks his garment clean of lice, so he will pick Egypt clean and depart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There in the temple of the sun in Egypt he will demolish the sacred pillars and will burn down the temples of the gods of Egypt.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This word came to Jeremiah concerning all the Jews living in Lower Egypt – in Migdol, Tahpanhes and Memphis – and in Upper Egypt:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘This is what the Lord Almighty, the God of Israel, says: you saw the great disaster I brought on Jerusalem and on all the towns of Judah. Today they lie deserted and in ruins
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because of the evil they have done. They aroused my anger by burning incense to and worshipping other gods that neither they nor you nor your ancestors ever knew.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Again and again I sent my servants the prophets, who said, “Do not do this detestable thing that I hate!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But they did not listen or pay attention; they did not turn from their wickedness or stop burning incense to other gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, my fierce anger was poured out; it raged against the towns of Judah and the streets of Jerusalem and made them the desolate ruins they are today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Now this is what the Lord God Almighty, the God of Israel, says: why bring such great disaster on yourselves by cutting off from Judah the men and women, the children and infants, and so leave yourselves without a remnant?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why arouse my anger with what your hands have made, burning incense to other gods in Egypt, where you have come to live? You will destroy yourselves and make yourselves a curse and an object of reproach among all the nations on earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Have you forgotten the wickedness committed by your ancestors and by the kings and queens of Judah and the wickedness committed by you and your wives in the land of Judah and the streets of Jerusalem?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: To this day they have not humbled themselves or shown reverence, nor have they followed my law and the decrees I set before you and your ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Therefore this is what the Lord Almighty, the God of Israel, says: I am determined to bring disaster on you and to destroy all Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will take away the remnant of Judah who were determined to go to Egypt to settle there. They will all perish in Egypt; they will fall by the sword or die from famine. From the least to the greatest, they will die by sword or famine. They will become a curse and an object of horror, a curse and an object of reproach.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will punish those who live in Egypt with the sword, famine and plague, as I punished Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: None of the remnant of Judah who have gone to live in Egypt will escape or survive to return to the land of Judah, to which they long to return and live; none will return except a few fugitives.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the men who knew that their wives were burning incense to other gods, along with all the women who were present – a large assembly – and all the people living in Lower and Upper Egypt, said to Jeremiah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘We will not listen to the message you have spoken to us in the name of the Lord!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We will certainly do everything we said we would: we will burn incense to the Queen of Heaven and will pour out drink offerings to her just as we and our ancestors, our kings and our officials did in the towns of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem. At that time we had plenty of food and were well off and suffered no harm.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But ever since we stopped burning incense to the Queen of Heaven and pouring out drink offerings to her, we have had nothing and have been perishing by sword and famine.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The women added, ‘When we burned incense to the Queen of Heaven and poured out drink offerings to her, did not our husbands know that we were making cakes impressed with her image and pouring out drink offerings to her?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeremiah said to all the people, both men and women, who were answering him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Did not the Lord remember and call to mind the incense burned in the towns of Judah and the streets of Jerusalem by you and your ancestors, your kings and your officials and the people of the land?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Lord could no longer endure your wicked actions and the detestable things you did, your land became a curse and a desolate waste without inhabitants, as it is today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because you have burned incense and have sinned against the Lord and have not obeyed him or followed his law or his decrees or his stipulations, this disaster has come upon you, as you now see.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeremiah said to all the people, including the women, ‘Hear the word of the Lord, all you people of Judah in Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord Almighty, the God of Israel, says: you and your wives have done what you said you would do when you promised, “We will certainly carry out the vows we made to burn incense and pour out drink offerings to the Queen of Heaven.”
‘Go ahead then, do what you promised! Keep your vows!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But hear the word of the Lord, all you Jews living in Egypt: “I swear by my great name,” says the Lord, “that no one from Judah living anywhere in Egypt shall ever again invoke my name or swear, ‘As surely as the Sovereign Lord lives.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For I am watching over them for harm, not for good; the Jews in Egypt will perish by sword and famine until they are all destroyed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Those who escape the sword and return to the land of Judah from Egypt will be very few. Then the whole remnant of Judah who came to live in Egypt will know whose word will stand – mine or theirs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘“This will be the sign to you that I will punish you in this place,” declares the Lord, “so that you will know that my threats of harm against you will surely stand.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord says: “I am going to deliver Pharaoh Hophra king of Egypt into the hands of his enemies who want to kill him, just as I gave Zedekiah king of Judah into the hands of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, the enemy who wanted to kill him.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Baruch son of Neriah wrote on a scroll the words Jeremiah the prophet dictated in the fourth year of Jehoiakim son of Josiah king of Judah, Jeremiah said this to Baruch:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says to you, Baruch:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You said, “Woe to me! The Lord has added sorrow to my pain; I am worn out with groaning and find no rest.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord has told me to say to you, “This is what the Lord says: I will overthrow what I have built and uproot what I have planted, throughout the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Should you then seek great things for yourself? Do not seek them. For I will bring disaster on all people, declares the Lord, but wherever you go I will let you escape with your life.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the word of the Lord that came to Jeremiah the prophet concerning the nations:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Concerning Egypt:
This is the message against the army of Pharaoh Necho king of Egypt, which was defeated at Carchemish on the River Euphrates by Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon in the fourth year of Jehoiakim son of Josiah king of Judah:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Prepare your shields, both large and small,
    and march out for battle!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Harness the horses,
    mount the steeds!
Take your positions
    with helmets on!
Polish your spears,
    put on your armour!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What do I see?
    They are terrified,
they are retreating,
    their warriors are defeated.
They flee in haste
    without looking back,
    and there is terror on every side,’
declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘The swift cannot flee
    nor the strong escape.
In the north by the River Euphrates
    they stumble and fall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Who is this that rises like the Nile,
    like rivers of surging waters?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Egypt rises like the Nile,
    like rivers of surging waters.
She says, “I will rise and cover the earth;
    I will destroy cities and their people.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Charge, you horses!
    Drive furiously, you charioteers!
March on, you warriors – men of Cush and Put who carry shields,
    men of Lydia who draw the bow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But that day belongs to the Lord, the Lord Almighty –
    a day of vengeance, for vengeance on his foes.
The sword will devour till it is satisfied,
    till it has quenched its thirst with blood.
For the Lord, the Lord Almighty, will offer sacrifice
    in the land of the north by the River Euphrates.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Go up to Gilead and get balm,
    Virgin Daughter Egypt.
But you try many medicines in vain;
    there is no healing for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text: This is the message the Lord spoke to Jeremiah the prophet about the coming of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon to attack Egypt:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Announce this in Egypt, and proclaim it in Migdol;
    proclaim it also in Memphis and Tahpanhes:
“Take your positions and get ready,
    for the sword devours those around you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why will your warriors be laid low?
    They cannot stand, for the Lord will push them down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They will stumble repeatedly;
    they will fall over each other.
They will say, “Get up, let us go back
    to our own people and our native lands,
    away from the sword of the oppressor.”
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
‘As surely as I live,’ declares the King,
    whose name is the Lord Almighty,
‘one will come who is like Tabor among the mountains,
    like Carmel by the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Pack your belongings for exile,
    you who live in Egypt,
for Memphis will be laid waste
    and lie in ruins without inhabitant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Egypt is a beautiful heifer,
    but a gadfly is coming
    against her from the north.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The mercenaries in her ranks
    are like fattened calves.
They too will turn and flee together,
    they will not stand their ground,
for the day of disaster is coming upon them,
    the time for them to be punished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Egypt will hiss like a fleeing serpent
    as the enemy advances in force;
they will come against her with axes,
    like men who cut down trees.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They will chop down her forest,’
declares the Lord,
    ‘dense though it be.
They are more numerous than locusts,
    they cannot be counted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Daughter Egypt will be put to shame,
    given into the hands of the people of the north.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord Almighty, the God of Israel, says: ‘I am about to bring punishment on Amon god of Thebes, on Pharaoh, on Egypt and her gods and her kings, and on those who rely on Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will give them into the hands of those who want to kill them – Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon and his officers. Later, however, Egypt will be inhabited as in times past,’ declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Do not be afraid, Jacob my servant;
    do not be dismayed, Israel.
I will surely save you out of a distant place,
    your descendants from the land of their exile.
Jacob will again have peace and security,
    and no one will make him afraid.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not be afraid, Jacob my servant,
    for I am with you,’ declares the Lord.
‘Though I completely destroy all the nations
    among which I scatter you,
    I will not completely destroy you.
I will discipline you but only in due measure;
    I will not let you go entirely unpunished.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the word of the Lord that came to Jeremiah the prophet concerning the Philistines before Pharaoh attacked Gaza:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord says:
‘See how the waters are rising in the north;
    they will become an overflowing torrent.
They will overflow the land and everything in it,
    the towns and those who live in them.
The people will cry out;
    all who dwell in the land will wail
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
at the sound of the hooves of galloping steeds,
    at the noise of enemy chariots
    and the rumble of their wheels.
Parents will not turn to help their children;
    their hands will hang limp.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For the day has come
    to destroy all the Philistines
and to remove all survivors
    who could help Tyre and Sidon.
The Lord is about to destroy the Philistines,
    the remnant from the coasts of Caphtor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Gaza will shave her head in mourning;
    Ashkelon will be silenced.
You remnant on the plain,
    how long will you cut yourselves?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘“Alas, sword of the Lord,
    how long till you rest?
Return to your sheath;
    cease and be still.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But how can it rest
    when the Lord has commanded it,
when he has ordered it
    to attack Ashkelon and the coast?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Concerning Moab:
This is what the Lord Almighty, the God of Israel, says:
‘Woe to Nebo, for it will be ruined.
    Kiriathaim will be disgraced and captured;
    the stronghold will be disgraced and shattered.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Cries of anguish arise from Horonaim,
    cries of great havoc and destruction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Moab will be broken;
    her little ones will cry out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They go up the hill to Luhith,
    weeping bitterly as they go;
on the road down to Horonaim
    anguished cries over the destruction are heard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Flee! Run for your lives;
    become like a bush in the desert.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Since you trust in your deeds and riches,
    you too will be taken captive,
and Chemosh will go into exile,
    together with his priests and officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The destroyer will come against every town,
    and not a town will escape.
The valley will be ruined
    and the plateau destroyed,
    because the Lord has spoken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Put salt on Moab,
    for she will be laid waste;
her towns will become desolate,
    with no one to live in them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘A curse on anyone who is lax in doing the Lord’s work!
    A curse on anyone who keeps their sword from bloodshed!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Moab has been at rest from youth,
    like wine left on its dregs,
not poured from one jar to another –
    she has not gone into exile.
So she tastes as she did,
    and her aroma is unchanged.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But days are coming,’
    declares the Lord,
‘when I will send men who pour from pitchers,
    and they will pour her out;
they will empty her pitchers
    and smash her jars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Moab will be ashamed of Chemosh,
    as Israel was ashamed
    when they trusted in Bethel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘How can you say, “We are warriors,
    men valiant in battle”?
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
‘The fall of Moab is at hand;
    her calamity will come quickly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Mourn for her, all who live around her,
    all who know her fame;
say, “How broken is the mighty sceptre,
    how broken the glorious staff!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Come down from your glory
    and sit on the parched ground,
    you inhabitants of Daughter Dibon,
for the one who destroys Moab
    will come up against you
    and ruin your fortified cities.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Stand by the road and watch,
    you who live in Aroer.
Ask the man fleeing and the woman escaping,
    ask them, “What has happened?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Moab is disgraced, for she is shattered.
    Wail and cry out!
Announce by the Arnon
    that Moab is destroyed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Judgment has come to the plateau –
    to Holon, Jahzah and Mephaath,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: to Dibon, Nebo and Beth Diblathaim,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: to Kiriathaim, Beth Gamul and Beth Meon,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
to Kerioth and Bozrah –
    to all the towns of Moab, far and near.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
‘Make her drunk,
    for she has defied the Lord.
Let Moab wallow in her vomit;
    let her be an object of ridicule.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Was not Israel the object of your ridicule?
    Was she caught among thieves,
that you shake your head in scorn
    whenever you speak of her?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Abandon your towns and dwell among the rocks,
    you who live in Moab.
Be like a dove that makes its nest
    at the mouth of a cave.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘We have heard of Moab’s pride –
    how great is her arrogance! –
of her insolence, her pride, her conceit
    and the haughtiness of her heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I know her insolence but it is futile,’
declares the Lord,
    ‘and her boasts accomplish nothing.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
I weep for you, as Jazer weeps,
    you vines of Sibmah.
Your branches spread as far as the sea;
    they reached as far as Jazer.
The destroyer has fallen
    on your ripened fruit and grapes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Joy and gladness are gone
    from the orchards and fields of Moab.
I have stopped the flow of wine from the presses;
    no one treads them with shouts of joy.
Although there are shouts,
    they are not shouts of joy.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
In Moab I will put an end
    to those who make offerings on the high places
    and burn incense to their gods,’
declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Every head is shaved
    and every beard cut off;
every hand is slashed
    and every waist is covered with sackcloth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
On all the roofs in Moab
    and in the public squares
there is nothing but mourning,
    for I have broken Moab
    like a jar that no one wants,’
declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘How shattered she is! How they wail!
    How Moab turns her back in shame!
Moab has become an object of ridicule,
    an object of horror to all those around her.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord says:
‘Look! An eagle is swooping down,
    spreading its wings over Moab.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Kerioth will be captured
    and the strongholds taken.
In that day the hearts of Moab’s warriors
    will be like the heart of a woman in labour.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Moab will be destroyed as a nation
    because she defied the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Terror and pit and snare await you,
    you people of Moab,’
declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Whoever flees from the terror
    will fall into a pit,
whoever climbs out of the pit
    will be caught in a snare;
for I will bring on Moab
    the year of her punishment,’
declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Woe to you, Moab!
    The people of Chemosh are destroyed;
your sons are taken into exile
    and your daughters into captivity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Yet I will restore the fortunes of Moab
    in days to come,’
declares the Lord.
Here ends the judgment on Moab.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Concerning the Ammonites:
This is what the Lord says:
‘Has Israel no sons?
    Has Israel no heir?
Why then has Molek taken possession of Gad?
    Why do his people live in its towns?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But the days are coming,’
    declares the Lord,
‘when I will sound the battle cry
    against Rabbah of the Ammonites;
it will become a mound of ruins,
    and its surrounding villages will be set on fire.
Then Israel will drive out
    those who drove her out,’
says the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Why do you boast of your valleys,
    boast of your valleys so fruitful?
Unfaithful Daughter Ammon,
    you trust in your riches and say,
    “Who will attack me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will bring terror on you
    from all those around you,’
declares the Lord,
the Lord Almighty.
‘Every one of you will be driven away,
    and no one will gather the fugitives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Yet afterwards, I will restore the fortunes of the Ammonites,’
declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Concerning Edom:
This is what the Lord Almighty says:
‘Is there no longer wisdom in Teman?
    Has counsel perished from the prudent?
    Has their wisdom decayed?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Turn and flee, hide in deep caves,
    you who live in Dedan,
for I will bring disaster on Esau
    at the time when I punish him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If grape-pickers came to you,
    would they not leave a few grapes?
If thieves came during the night,
    would they not steal only as much as they wanted?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But I will strip Esau bare;
    I will uncover his hiding-places,
    so that he cannot conceal himself.
His armed men are destroyed,
    also his allies and neighbours,
    so there is no one to say,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Leave your fatherless children; I will keep them alive.
    Your widows too can depend on me.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord says: ‘If those who do not deserve to drink the cup must drink it, why should you go unpunished? You will not go unpunished, but must drink it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I swear by myself,’ declares the Lord, ‘that Bozrah will become a ruin and a curse, an object of horror and reproach; and all its towns will be in ruins for ever.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have heard a message from the Lord;
    an envoy was sent to the nations to say,
‘Assemble yourselves to attack it!
    Rise up for battle!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Now I will make you small among the nations,
    despised by mankind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The terror you inspire
    and the pride of your heart have deceived you,
you who live in the clefts of the rocks,
    who occupy the heights of the hill.
Though you build your nest as high as the eagle’s,
    from there I will bring you down,’
declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
As Sodom and Gomorrah were overthrown,
    along with their neighbouring towns,’
says the Lord,
‘so no one will live there;
    no people will dwell in it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Like a lion coming up from Jordan’s thickets
    to a rich pasture-land,
I will chase Edom from its land in an instant.
    Who is the chosen one I will appoint for this?
Who is like me and who can challenge me?
    And what shepherd can stand against me?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore, hear what the Lord has planned against Edom,
    what he has purposed against those who live in Teman:
the young of the flock will be dragged away;
    their pasture will be appalled at their fate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
At the sound of their fall the earth will tremble;
    their cry will resound to the Red Sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look! An eagle will soar and swoop down,
    spreading its wings over Bozrah.
In that day the hearts of Edom’s warriors
    will be like the heart of a woman in labour.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Concerning Damascus:
‘Hamath and Arpad are dismayed,
    for they have heard bad news.
They are disheartened,
    troubled like the restless sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Damascus has become feeble,
    she has turned to flee
    and panic has gripped her;
anguish and pain have seized her,
    pain like that of a woman in labour.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why has the city of renown not been abandoned,
    the town in which I delight?
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
‘I will set fire to the walls of Damascus;
    it will consume the fortresses of Ben-Hadad.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Concerning Kedar and the kingdoms of Hazor, which Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon attacked:
This is what the Lord says:
‘Arise, and attack Kedar
    and destroy the people of the East.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their tents and their flocks will be taken;
    their shelters will be carried off
    with all their goods and camels.
People will shout to them,
    “Terror on every side!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Flee quickly away!
    Stay in deep caves, you who live in Hazor,’
declares the Lord.
‘Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon has plotted against you;
    he has devised a plan against you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Arise and attack a nation at ease,
    which lives in confidence,’
declares the Lord,
‘a nation that has neither gates nor bars;
    its people live far from danger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their camels will become plunder,
    and their large herds will be spoils of war.
I will scatter to the winds those who are in distant places
    and will bring disaster on them from every side,’
declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Hazor will become a haunt of jackals,
    a desolate place for ever.
No one will live there;
    no people will dwell in it.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the word of the Lord that came to Jeremiah the prophet concerning Elam, early in the reign of Zedekiah king of Judah:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord Almighty says:
‘See, I will break the bow of Elam,
    the mainstay of their might.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will bring against Elam the four winds
    from the four quarters of heaven;
I will scatter them to the four winds,
    and there will not be a nation
    where Elam’s exiles do not go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will shatter Elam before their foes,
    before those who want to kill them;
I will bring disaster on them,
    even my fierce anger,’
declares the Lord.
‘I will pursue them with the sword
    until I have made an end of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will set my throne in Elam
    and destroy her king and officials,’
declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Yet I will restore the fortunes of Elam
    in days to come,’
declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the word the Lord spoke through Jeremiah the prophet concerning Babylon and the land of the Babylonians:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Announce and proclaim among the nations,
    lift up a banner and proclaim it;
    keep nothing back, but say,
“Babylon will be captured;
    Bel will be put to shame,
    Marduk filled with terror.
Her images will be put to shame
    and her idols filled with terror.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A nation from the north will attack her
    and lay waste her land.
No one will live in it;
    both people and animals will flee away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘In those days, at that time,’
    declares the Lord,
‘the people of Israel and the people of Judah together
    will go in tears to seek the Lord their God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They will ask the way to Zion
    and turn their faces towards it.
They will come and bind themselves to the Lord
    in an everlasting covenant
    that will not be forgotten.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘My people have been lost sheep;
    their shepherds have led them astray
    and caused them to roam on the mountains.
They wandered over mountain and hill
    and forgot their own resting place.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
For I will stir up and bring against Babylon
    an alliance of great nations from the land of the north.
They will take up their positions against her,
    and from the north she will be captured.
Their arrows will be like skilled warriors
    who do not return empty-handed.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
‘Because you rejoice and are glad,
    you who pillage my inheritance,
because you frolic like a heifer threshing corn
    and neigh like stallions,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
your mother will be greatly ashamed;
    she who gave you birth will be disgraced.
She will be the least of the nations –
    a wilderness, a dry land, a desert.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Because of the Lord’s anger she will not be inhabited
    but will be completely desolate.
All who pass Babylon will be appalled;
    they will scoff because of all her wounds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Take up your positions round Babylon,
    all you who draw the bow.
Shoot at her! Spare no arrows,
    for she has sinned against the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Shout against her on every side!
    She surrenders, her towers fall,
    her walls are torn down.
Since this is the vengeance of the Lord,
    take vengeance on her;
    do to her as she has done to others.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Cut off from Babylon the sower,
    and the reaper with his sickle at harvest.
Because of the sword of the oppressor
    let everyone return to their own people,
    let everyone flee to their own land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Israel is a scattered flock
    that lions have chased away.
The first to devour them
    was the king of Assyria;
the last to crush their bones
    was Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore this is what the Lord Almighty, the God of Israel, says:
‘I will punish the king of Babylon and his land
    as I punished the king of Assyria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But I will bring Israel back to their own pasture,
    and they will graze on Carmel and Bashan;
their appetite will be satisfied
    on the hills of Ephraim and Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In those days, at that time,’
    declares the Lord,
‘search will be made for Israel’s guilt,
    but there will be none,
and for the sins of Judah,
    but none will be found,
    for I will forgive the remnant I spare.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Attack the land of Merathaim
    and those who live in Pekod.
Pursue, kill and completely destroy them,’
declares the Lord.
    ‘Do everything I have commanded you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The noise of battle is in the land,
    the noise of great destruction!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How broken and shattered
    is the hammer of the whole earth!
How desolate is Babylon
    among the nations!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I set a trap for you, Babylon,
    and you were caught before you knew it;
you were found and captured
    because you opposed the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord has opened his arsenal
    and brought out the weapons of his wrath,
for the Sovereign Lord Almighty has work to do
    in the land of the Babylonians.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Come against her from afar.
    Break open her granaries;
    pile her up like heaps of grain.
Completely destroy her
    and leave her no remnant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Kill all her young bulls;
    let them go down to the slaughter!
Woe to them! For their day has come,
    the time for them to be punished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Listen to the fugitives and refugees from Babylon
    declaring in Zion
how the Lord our God has taken vengeance,
    vengeance for his temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Summon archers against Babylon,
    all those who draw the bow.
Encamp all round her;
    let no one escape.
Repay her for her deeds;
    do to her as she has done.
For she defied the Lord,
    the Holy One of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
‘See, I am against you, you arrogant one,’
    declares the Lord, the Lord Almighty,
‘for your day has come,
    the time for you to be punished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The arrogant one will stumble and fall
    and no one will help her up;
I will kindle a fire in her towns
    that will consume all who are around her.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord Almighty says:
‘The people of Israel are oppressed,
    and the people of Judah as well.
All their captors hold them fast,
    refusing to let them go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yet their Redeemer is strong;
    the Lord Almighty is his name.
He will vigorously defend their cause
    so that he may bring rest to their land,
    but unrest to those who live in Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘A sword against the Babylonians!’
    declares the Lord –
‘against those who live in Babylon
    and against her officials and wise men!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A sword against her false prophets!
    They will become fools.
A sword against her warriors!
    They will be filled with terror.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A sword against her horses and chariots
    and all the foreigners in her ranks!
    They will become weaklings.
A sword against her treasures!
    They will be plundered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A drought on her waters!
    They will dry up.
For it is a land of idols,
    idols that will go mad with terror.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘So desert creatures and hyenas will live there,
    and there the owl will dwell.
It will never again be inhabited
    or lived in from generation to generation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As I overthrew Sodom and Gomorrah
    along with their neighbouring towns,’
declares the Lord,
‘so no one will live there;
    no people will dwell in it.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
The king of Babylon has heard reports about them,
    and his hands hang limp.
Anguish has gripped him,
    pain like that of a woman in labour.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a lion coming up from Jordan’s thickets
    to a rich pasture-land,
I will chase Babylon from its land in an instant.
    Who is the chosen one I will appoint for this?
Who is like me and who can challenge me?
    And what shepherd can stand against me?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore, hear what the Lord has planned against Babylon,
    what he has purposed against the land of the Babylonians:
the young of the flock will be dragged away;
    their pasture will be appalled at their fate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
At the sound of Babylon’s capture the earth will tremble;
    its cry will resound among the nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord says:
‘See, I will stir up the spirit of a destroyer
    against Babylon and the people of Leb Kamai.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will send foreigners to Babylon
    to winnow her and to devastate her land;
they will oppose her on every side
    in the day of her disaster.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let not the archer string his bow,
    nor let him put on his armour.
Do not spare her young men;
    completely destroy her army.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They will fall down slain in Babylon,
    fatally wounded in her streets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For Israel and Judah have not been forsaken
    by their God, the Lord Almighty,
though their land is full of guilt
    before the Holy One of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Flee from Babylon!
    Run for your lives!
    Do not be destroyed because of her sins.
It is time for the Lord’s vengeance;
    he will repay her what she deserves.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Babylon will suddenly fall and be broken.
    Wail over her!
Get balm for her pain;
    perhaps she can be healed.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
‘Sharpen the arrows,
    take up the shields!
The Lord has stirred up the kings of the Medes,
    because his purpose is to destroy Babylon.
The Lord will take vengeance,
    vengeance for his temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Lift up a banner against the walls of Babylon!
    Reinforce the guard,
station the watchmen,
    prepare an ambush!
The Lord will carry out his purpose,
    his decree against the people of Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You who live by many waters
    and are rich in treasures,
your end has come,
    the time for you to be destroyed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord Almighty has sworn by himself:
    I will surely fill you with troops, as with a swarm of locusts,
    and they will shout in triumph over you.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
When he thunders, the waters in the heavens roar;
    he makes clouds rise from the ends of the earth.
He sends lightning with the rain
    and brings out the wind from his storehouses.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
They are worthless, the objects of mockery;
    when their judgment comes, they will perish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who is the Portion of Jacob is not like these,
    for he is the Maker of all things,
including the people of his inheritance –
    the Lord Almighty is his name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘You are my war club,
    my weapon for battle –
with you I shatter nations,
    with you I destroy kingdoms,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
with you I shatter horse and rider,
    with you I shatter chariot and driver,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
with you I shatter man and woman,
    with you I shatter old man and youth,
    with you I shatter young man and young woman,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
with you I shatter shepherd and flock,
    with you I shatter farmer and oxen,
    with you I shatter governors and officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Before your eyes I will repay Babylon and all who live in Babylonia for all the wrong they have done in Zion,’ declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘I am against you, you destroying mountain,
    you who destroy the whole earth,’
declares the Lord.
‘I will stretch out my hand against you,
    roll you off the cliffs,
    and make you a burnt-out mountain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
No rock will be taken from you for a cornerstone,
    nor any stone for a foundation,
    for you will be desolate for ever,’
declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Lift up a banner in the land!
    Blow the trumpet among the nations!
Prepare the nations for battle against her;
    summon against her these kingdoms:
    Ararat, Minni and Ashkenaz.
Appoint a commander against her;
    send up horses like a swarm of locusts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Prepare the nations for battle against her –
    the kings of the Medes,
their governors and all their officials,
    and all the countries they rule.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The land trembles and writhes,
    for the Lord’s purposes against Babylon stand –
to lay waste the land of Babylon
    so that no one will live there.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
One courier follows another
    and messenger follows messenger
to announce to the king of Babylon
    that his entire city is captured,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the river crossings seized,
    the marshes set on fire,
    and the soldiers terrified.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord Almighty, the God of Israel, says:
‘Daughter Babylon is like a threshing-floor
    at the time it is trampled;
    the time to harvest her will soon come.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon has devoured us,
    he has thrown us into confusion,
    he has made us an empty jar.
Like a serpent he has swallowed us
    and filled his stomach with our delicacies,
    and then has spewed us out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
May the violence done to our flesh be on Babylon,’
    say the inhabitants of Zion.
‘May our blood be on those who live in Babylonia,’
    says Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore this is what the Lord says:
‘See, I will defend your cause
    and avenge you;
I will dry up her sea
    and make her springs dry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Babylon will be a heap of ruins,
    a haunt of jackals,
an object of horror and scorn,
    a place where no one lives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Her people all roar like young lions,
    they growl like lion cubs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But while they are aroused,
    I will set out a feast for them
    and make them drunk,
so that they shout with laughter –
    then sleep for ever and not awake,’
declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘I will bring them down
    like lambs to the slaughter,
    like rams and goats.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘How Sheshak will be captured,
    the boast of the whole earth seized!
How desolate Babylon will be
    among the nations!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sea will rise over Babylon;
    its roaring waves will cover her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Her towns will be desolate,
    a dry and desert land,
a land where no one lives,
    through which no one travels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will punish Bel in Babylon
    and make him spew out what he has swallowed.
The nations will no longer stream to him.
    And the wall of Babylon will fall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Come out of her, my people!
    Run for your lives!
    Run from the fierce anger of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not lose heart or be afraid
    when rumours are heard in the land;
one rumour comes this year, another the next,
    rumours of violence in the land
    and of ruler against ruler.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
